newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL interbank rates fall further on liquidity.
newsitem.headline: KL interbank rates fall further on liquidity.

text.p: Interbank rates fell further on Wednesday due to improving liquidity and continued aggressive lending by big local banks as well as foreign banks, dealers said.
"Short-end rates are falling very fast and the one- and three-month money is also coming off," said a dealer at a Malaysian bank. "The big banks are long and still lending."
He said players borrowing at the far end of the yield curve on concerns over the Thai baht were lending aggressively at the short-end.
The fall in rates on Wednesday came on the back of maturity of a 500-million ringgit Bank Negara bill issue which further improved market liquidity.
Bank Negara bills worth 1.5 billion ringgit had matured last week. The central bank has not announced any new issue to roll-over the maturities.
Dealers said the focus will be on whether a Bank Negara lending maturity on Thursday, said to be for two billion ringgit, will bring rates back up again.
One-week money was at 6.60/70 percent against 7.20 percent on Tuesday, dealers said.
One-month money was at 7.45 percent from 7.55, and three-month at 7.55 percent against 7.60.
The overnight rate was expected to stay around 5.8 percent, dealers said.
There has been speculation the central bank, through its agent banks, has been supporting the overnight from falling below its perceived floor of 5.80 percent.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange posted small gains.
At 0330 GMT, the three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) September contract was up one point to 92.57, or an implied yield of 7.43 percent.
The December contract rose two to 92.68, or 7.32 percent and March 1998 was also up two to 92.76, or 7.24 percent.
